alternatives.transcript: hello welcome back to the CBC Morning News I'm Bill Cameron I'm normally McLeod a big decision from the Supreme Court of Canada today the court has struck down Canada's tobacco laws laws which banned tobacco advertising in this country Deborah Brown is with us now from Ottawa as we stand by waiting for the tobacco companies to react to the court decision so Deborah basically advertising is once again allowed that that's the Crux of the decisions correct just quickly normally because

just about to start the news conference it was a landmark ruling 54 very close Split Decision here and it upholds the law it says that this law is a law the federal government is a it's within its jurisdiction it's unconstitutional because it violates freedom of expression and it not only affects the advertising in newspapers store promotions and billboards but also affects what they call unattributed Health warnings the new health warnings that are on the that are on the packages now we have a news conference

cigarettes in Canada and in the name of the three member companies mr. Parker has written to the minister of Health in order to share our commitment that is to act as though the law still wasn't effect and to allow us to pursue consultations

you people would resume your advertising could have cynics say that your decision today to play by the rules that have been struck down as a bit of a public relations maneuver to buy some time and that we will see a resumption of advertising in the near future no it isn't a public relations Ploy at all I'd point out that the decision was taken several weeks ago and communicated to all governments 10 provinces in the federal government earlier this week in fact starting lost

Friday night because we didn't know until two hours ago what was in the decision it's a complicated case and it could have gone in any way the court decision is essentially that communication advertising with customers is permitted to the total ban was not justified under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms I think it's important to understand that advertising of tobacco in Canada for a long long time has been subject to restrictions

voluntary restrictions imposed by the companies themselves radio and television advertising for example disappeared in Canada almost 30 years ago 1972 the band that was imposed by the law in 1989 eliminated all forms of advertising but what the court decision says and we're still studying it is that while a ban on Advertising is not justified restrictions are Justified and we expect to be discussing with

there's an advertising that's a possibility but I can't speculate that this will be on Plain packaging it's hard to say I mean I thought all along that plain packaging would fail as an initiative of its own weight we've argued even before this court decision that there is no evidence whatever of any substance to support the contention that plain packaging would lead to a reduction in consumption and that is paralleled in fact by something the court said in this decision
